items.title: Ski resort management, union called to meeting day after Quebec's Le Massif closed for season
items.summary_auto: Management at Le Massif de Charlevoix and its striking unionized employees have been called to a meeting just one day after the resort announced the cancellation of its ski season.

items.title: B.C.'s balmy January brings out blossoms, but a cold snap could put plants in peril
items.summary_auto: An unseasonably mild winter is coaxing blossoms to bloom early in some Metro Vancouver neighbourhoods, as it experiences one of the warmest Januaries on record.

items.title: Calgary father arrested in Mauritius, accused of abducting son 2 years ago
items.summary_auto: A Calgary mother has been reunited with her son after police arrested the boy’s father in Mauritius, more than two years after he’s accused of abducting the then-five-year-old.

items.title: Canada's Paralympic hockey roster to include 10 players from 2022 silver medal squad
items.summary_auto: Veteran forward Greg Westlake will head to his sixth Paralympic Games as Canada's Para hockey team looks for its first Olympic gold medal in 20 years at the Milan-Cortina Winter Paralympics.

items.title: Ontario pins hopes on storage batteries to sustain struggling EV supply chain
items.summary_auto: Ontario's vision for an end-to-end electric vehicle supply chain, once an aggressive focus for Premier Doug Ford, has been sputtering as manufacturers delay or cancel plans, and the government is now looking to demands for batteries of a different sort to sustain it.

items.title: Midnight Oil drummer, co-founder Rob Hirst dead at 70
items.summary_auto: Australian band Midnight Oil announced on Tuesday that Rob Hirst, their powerhouse drummer and co-founding member, has died at age 70.

items.title: 'Our hearts are shattered,' says father of Canadian found dead on Australia beach
Former Ont. art teacher, 88, sentenced to over 5 years in prison for 1980s sexual assaults
items.summary_auto: A former elementary school teacher from Burlington, Ont., has been sentenced for sexually assaulting seven male students in the 1980s. Court heard victim impact statements at the hearing for the 88-year-old.

items.title: Syria gives Kurdish-led forces 4 days to accept integration as U.S. signals end of support
items.summary_auto: Syria on Tuesday announced a ceasefire with Kurdish forces it has seized swathes of territory from in the northeast and gave them four days to agree on integrating into the central state, which their main ally, the United States, urged them to accept.

items.title: Europe's far-right parties, often praised by Trump administration, push back on Greenland
items.summary_auto: It wasn't too long ago that Donald Trump's administration hailed the "growing influence of patriotic European parties," but many of those party leaders have taken exception to his aggressive bid to seize control of Greenland for the United States.

items.title: Trump threatens 200% tariffs on French wines to get Macron on 'Board of Peace'
items.summary_auto: French President Emmanuel Macron said Europe would not give in to bullies or be intimidated in a scathing criticism of U.S. President Donald Trump's threat to impose steep tariffs if Europe does not let him take over Greenland.

items.title: Penguins break records by moving breeding season in warming climate
items.summary_auto: Penguins in Antarctica are changing their breeding habits at record speed to survive rising temperatures from climate change, a decade-long study has found.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Solar flare brings northern lights display
items.summary_auto: A solar storm brought colourful northern lights — a.k.a. aurora borealis — across Canada, the United States and parts of Europe Monday night.

items.title: Trump shares photo of Canada, Greenland as part of U.S. in map
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump shared an altered image of a map of the United States that includes Canada, Greenland, Venezuela and Cuba as part of its territory. The original image is from August, when NATO leaders including U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron visited Trump in the Oval Office.

items.title: Abi Strate leads Canadian Olympic ski jumping hopes at Milano-Cortina Winter Games
items.summary_auto: Canada’s newly named ski jumping team has high hopes heading into the Milano-Cortina Winter Games – and that has a lot to do with Abi Strate.

items.title: Wall Street slips after Trump threatens some NATO members with tariffs over Greenland
items.summary_auto: Stocks are falling on Wall Street after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to hit eight NATO members with new tariffs as tensions escalate over his attempts to assert American control over Greenland.

items.title: Want tickets for Brad Gushue's last Brier on home ice? Act fast, says tournament vice-chair
items.summary_auto: The last full batch of tickets went on sale Tuesday at noon, with fans eager to snap them up in a hurry.

items.title: Katy Perry joins Trudeau in Davos to support former PM's speech on value of 'soft power'
items.summary_auto: Former prime minister Justin Trudeau and international pop star Katy Perry took their relationship to the next level, appearing together at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday, where Trudeau delivered a speech to the world's elite on the virtues of soft power.

items.title: It's U.S.A. vs. the World, led by Canada's Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, at the 2026 NBA All-Star game
items.summary_auto: The first-ever World team for the NBA All-Star Game is already looking loaded. And the fate of LeBron James' record streak of All-Star selections will now be decided by coaches, or perhaps even Commissioner Adam Silver.

items.title: UN condemns Israel's 'unprecedented' demolition of its Palestinian aid agency building in East Jerusalem
items.summary_auto: Israel demolished structures inside the UN Palestinian refugee agency's East Jerusalem compound ​on Tuesday after seizing the site last year, in an act condemned by the agency as a violation of international law.

items.title: Finance minister says Canada will not pay $1B US if it joins Trump's 'Board of Peace'
items.summary_auto: Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne said on Tuesday that Ottawa does not plan to pay the $1-billion US price tag for a permanent seat on U.S. President Donald Trump's "Board of Peace," that will oversee the governance and reconstruction of Gaza.

items.title: Quebec latest province to take shot at Ontario premier’s upcoming Crown Royal whisky ban
items.summary_auto: Quebec Finance Minister Eric Girard says he has shared his concerns with his Ontario counterpart and says given trade tensions with the U-S, now is not the time for measures that weaken Canadian supply chains.

items.title: EU chief promises 'unflinching' response to new tariffs as Trump trolls and threatens on social media
items.summary_auto: European Commission President ​Ursula von der Leyen said ​on Tuesday the EU shared concerns with the United States about Arctic security, but if President Donald Trump followed through with new tariffs based on a dispute over Greenland, the alliance's response would be "unflinching" and "united."

items.title: Metal detectors coming to emergency rooms in Saskatoon and Regina
items.summary_auto: Metal detectors aimed at reducing violence in hospital emergency departments are coming to Saskatoon and Regina.

items.title: Indigenous man killed by RCMP remembered as a 'lovable' nephew and father
items.summary_auto: The aunt of a man who was shot and killed in his home by an RCMP officer in Neqotkuk First Nation shared fond memories of her nephew, Bronson Paul, and said she's "angry at the system" for his death.

items.title: This woman was misdiagnosed with bipolar disorder. It turns out she has a rare autoimmune disease instead
items.summary_auto: A relatively new class of autoimmune diseases that affect the brain is making psychiatrists rethink some diagnoses.

items.title: Remote workers at Global Affairs say they're being forced to transfer to capital
items.summary_auto: Public servants with Global Affairs Canada (GAC) who have been teleworking full-time for the past several years from cities such as Montreal are now being required to work in offices in the National Capital Region.

items.title: Montreal adults spending more of their free time on screens, public health finds
items.summary_auto: A new study released on Tuesday shows the proportion of individuals who use their screens more than two hours a day for leisure activities increased by 13 per cent between 2018 and 2025.

items.title: As AI moves into the physical world, is Canada missing the boat on robotics?
items.summary_auto: Canada is lagging in robotics adoption, industry watchers say, especially outside of the auto sector. At the same time, robots are taking off, thanks to a boom in China and new approaches incorporating AI. At a time when Canada is concerned about productivity, are we missing the boat?

items.title: How many military bases are there in the Arctic? Here are the facts
items.summary_auto: A vast portion of Arctic lands belong to Canada, but its military presence there is small compared to other countries, especially Russia and Norway.

items.title: Britain calls some anti-Israel protests a form of terrorism. Is it state overreach?
items.summary_auto: A trio of British hunger strikers is taking food again last week, after claiming victory in a standoff with the U.K. government over the group Palestine Action. The activist group, best known for vandalizing British companies associated with Israel, has been proscribed as a terrorist organization by the government.

items.title: No, accused drug lord Ryan Wedding isn’t posting pics on Instagram while fleeing the FBI
items.summary_auto: Tens of thousands of Instagram users appear to have been duped by an account purporting to belong to Canadian fugitive Ryan Wedding. Instead, a CBC News analysis finds the page features content generated by AI, including images showing a helicopter, a statuette of Wedding and an autographed motorbike.

items.title: How technology keeps transportation moving through thick fog
items.summary_auto: While dense fog continues blanketed parts of the Lower Mainland to start the week, sea and air transportation pressed on. As Troy Charles finds out, a combination of old and new technology is helping crews navigate the low visibility.

items.title: Alberta emergency doctors compile list of what they say are 6 potentially preventable ER deaths
items.summary_auto: Alberta emergency room doctors have counted what they say are six potentially preventable deaths as well as numerous close calls for patients who they say waited too long for care in emergency rooms across the province.

items.title: Heated Rivalry's François Arnaud calls on NHL to embrace diversity
items.summary_auto: Actor François Arnaud, who co-stars in the hit Canadian series Heated Rivalry, says while it seems the NHL has figured out that the steamy hockey romance is a big deal, he'd like to see the league do more to promote actual diversity on the ice, rather than just capitalize on the show's success for marketing purposes.

items.title: #TheMoment 4 metres of snow blanketed Russian towns
items.summary_auto: Shovelling hit new extremes in Russia’s Kamchatka peninsula after heavy snow buried cars and buildings, reaching a height of up to four metres in some areas, according to Russia's national weather service.
